values:
I am an essay. I am everything but inanimate: a student's spirit fills me. I am a student's story. 
The first time I saw her, her eyes were full of shooting stars, crashing waves, symphonies, all the excitement of a world only she could see. She clapped her hands and squealed, "Yes, yes! Oh, yes, how promising! Come with me, my masterpiece!" So I was born.

I knew my importance. She wore no make-up or stylish clothes, sat on the edges of the classroom where she could avoid eye contact, never spoke without being spoken to. She had been too self-conscious even to write in her diary. She wanted a second chance for respect -- a reason to respect herself. I was ready -- we both were. So she took me under her eager hands and started to write.

Most people her age dreaded writing an essay. But she loved her work, and she loved me. Every day I looked forward to watching that starry world of hers flash in her eyes as she wrote. She would laugh out loud whenever she got an idea, get up and pace, spin the new words aloud and even sing them.
But her life had a stickiness even our Pentecosts at the computer could purge only for so many hours. It was gradual, like aging, decaying: at first she worked with the same passion as before, but sometimes in her eyes, instead of that musical, shining world, I would see girls in school hallways pointing and whispering, boys snickering, teachers shaking their heads. Sometimes she would go whole days without working on me. She would play Minesweeper, Snood, doodle in her writing pad, while I waited, our deadline looming closer, my unfinished paragraphs dangling and fraying. I braced myself for my worst nightmare.
I knew it was time when she came home from school with tears staining her eyes and blocking that brilliant world from view. She threw herself on her chair, swiveled a few times, then choked the gunshot words: "I only have one more day to write this stupid essay."
The blow shattered my punctuation, and the phrases she had turned with such care scattered in the storm. She did not love me anymore. I looked at the Recycle Bin and thought about jumping in.

She sighed, poked a key, deleted, poked, deleted. I had to look away -- the opaque eyes chilled me...

i thank You God for most this amazing day:for the leaping greenly spirits of trees and a blue true dream of sky;and for everything which is natural which is infinite which is yes (i who have died am alive again today, and this is the sun's birthday;this is the birth day of life and love and wings:and of the gay great happening illimitably earth) how should tasting touching hearing seeing breathing any-lifted from the no of all nothing-human merely being doubt unimaginably You? (now the ears of my ears awake and now the eyes of my eyes are opened)

E. E. Cummings

I hold my breath
and let it hold me; water strokes my face.
Stone walls around me answer when I ask.
I'm tired; I crawl beneath a roof of space,
and even winter lets me have its blanket.
Dusk comes, death stays, I am never left
by ignorance.
                       So, soul-friend, take your seat.
The highest promise kills itself to try
to be the lowest draft across the sand,
broken, scattered, broken after passing
ghostlike through my fingers
when they try
to hold...

Blazing across the night sky like shards of broken stars float images of you flickering in the darkened haze of my memory stirring the warm ashes of longing to see you in the early morning light to hear your laughter from the next room to feel your hand resting on my shoulder to have you here once again.

R. Detorie

GRIEF (2005)
WHAT stole your breath
was fear of death,
not grief.
The air
that stung your eyes until they had to close
to the love still there
was fear of despair,
not grief.
Nor did grief have you thrown
into the empty cell of your thoughts,
where you knelt on your own,
sighed,
and waited;
that was fear of being alone.

Grief was left on the ground
when dawn came in -
a dewy blood
that rinsed your skin.
On those days when all the noise had stopped,
you swore
you heard music
you did not before.

Winds touch Branches brush a face looking back The dark green path The pearl gray sky Can you see the border? No one there The silence folds, unanswered questions team Dialogue of the deaf No way out Can you see the border? Darkness blinds And walls confine The world growing smaller still "Reality," he said, "is relative" If it's true That what you send comes back Then I fear for some "Reality," he said, "is relative"

Keri Steele

It makes for an amusing story how I got to writing this. I wrote, yes, before then - but I never spilled my blood and bile on the page. I only wrote what I could bear to have read over my shoulder - Dear Diary, what I did today; Dear Diary, what I have to do tomorrow; Dear Diary, what Veronica did today; Dear Diary, my trip to the library. Dear Diary, I was sitting on that stone bench under the honey locust as I always do, with this book on my lap, writing about what Veronica ate for dessert, when I wrote a foreign word. I erased it. But I wrote it again. Need I say I was puzzled? I considered, after many erasings and writings, erasing and writings of that same word, that I might as well finish the sentence. Then a paragraph. Then what was approaching the length of a novel. I hardly noticed the blank space disappear with the hours as the letters in their ranks subdued it, as the empire of words spread to every last empty line. Words I couldn't read. But words I understood. Words I would never have to read again, because they came from within, because anyone who has ever breathed the breath of life would know they are true, and truer than truth. --- Far from written out - for heaven's sake, the fire's just started! The flood. Out come the words from a reservoir, struck open - good God, what a blow! A flow, a torrent, drowning every blank line in its path...savage, voracious river-dragon with no ethic, no thought but to destroy! I catch on this page not a few drops of rain - it's pouring outside, and this leaf gets soaked with the five minutes God wrote in history.

From my teal journal, May 2005

I can't imagine anything but music that could have brought about this alchemy. Maybe it's because music is about as physical as it gets: your essential rhythm is your heartbeat; your essential sound, the breath. We're walking temples of noise, and when you add tender hearts to this mix, somehow it lets us meet in places we couldn't get to any other way.

Anne Lamott, Traveling Mercies

Thus, great with child to speak, and helpless in my throes, Biting my truant pen, beating myself for spite, "Fool," said my Muse to me, "look in thy heart, and write!"

Sir Philip Sidney, Astrophel and Stella

Come to the edge, He said. They said, We are afraid. Come to the edge, He said. They came. He pushed them... And they flew.

Guillaume Apollinaire
Future is a mosaic of decisions. -Anonymous I've never been afraid of silence; what scares me more are empty words. -Jenny Schuab, "This Piece of Earth"

Everywhere white and stained glass. Here, on this page, notes dip like a child learning to swim. In these sounds, I feel her drop to her knees, sink till eyes touch water, till she blows all air from her lungs. Or, on the next page, bells humming on a summer night in circles: louder, softer, farther. On this pew alone, a girl twisting her hair like a chain, a man, his voice a groan, a woman, pushing half-notes past the stone walls, out, over the hills. The boy beside me breathes in, out, loud, migrates toward the aisle, leaves me alone with a hymnbook, words I've known too long, trying not to breathe you in, not to breathe at all.

Marjorie Maddox

That was the day they killed the Son of God On a squat hill-top by Jerusalem. Zion was bare, her children from their maze Sucked by the demon curiosity Clean through the gates. The very halt and blind Had somehow got themselves up to the hill. After the ceremonial preparation, The scourging, nailing, nailing against the wood, Erection of the main-trees with their burden, While from the hill rose an orchestral wailing, They were there at last, high up in the soft spring day. We watched the writhings, heard the moanings, saw The three heads turning on their separate axles Like broken wheels left spinning. Round his head Was loosely bound a crown of plaited thorn That hurt at random, stinging temple and brow As the pain swung into its envious circle. In front the wreath was gathered in a knot That as he gazed looked like the last stump left Of a death-wounded deer's great antlers. Some Who came to stare grew silent as they looked, Indignant or sorry. But the hardened old And the hard-hearted young, although at odds From the first morning, cursed him with one curse, Having prayed for a Rabbi or an armed Messiah And found the Son of God. What use to them Was a God or a Son of God? Of what avail For purposes such as theirs? Beside the cross-foot, Alone, four women stood and did not move All day. The sun revolved, the shadows wheeled, The evening fell. His head lay on his breast, But in his breast they watched his heart move on By itself alone, accomplishing its journey. Their taunts grew louder, sharpened by the knowledge That he was walking in the park of death, Far from their rage. Yet all grew stale at last, Spite, curiosity, envy, hate itself. They waited only for death and death was slow And came so quietly they scarce could mark it. They were angry then with death and death's deceit. I was a stranger, could not read these people Or this outlandish deity. Did a God Indeed in dying cross my life that day By chance, he on his road and I on mine?

Edwin Muir

The snowflakes are falling to the ground, And it is very cold; To dress warmly, we are bound, Now do what you were just told. (1996, 9 years old) Flakes meander, cascade to the ground. The raw air is frigid against my skin... (2000, 13 years old) The flakes are lovely, their light appealing, But loftier light and beauty, in stealing My head, my heart, my name to its source, Leaves an empty person in the snow. (2004, 17 years old)

A cloud of flame rips through the air, Those left defenseless succumb to despair. The colossus falls, taking with it a mass, They were praying in vain for the terror to pass. From the shattered pride of a nation Rises a cry of desperation. Death's dismal presence sweeps over the sand, Casting its shadow on freedom's land. Yet, amid the perplexity and chaos, A pillar of hope still shines before us, Tall and majestic as ever before, Still lifting her lamp beside the golden door.

September 12, 2001

The gesture of a gift is adequate. If you have nothing: laurel leaf nor bay, No flower, no seed, no apple gathered late, Do not in desperation lay The beauty of your tears upon the clay. No gift is proper for a Deity. No fruit is worthy for such power to bless. If you have nothing, gather back your sigh, And with your hands held high, Your heart held high, Lift up your emptiness!

Jessica Powers

And when I looked in her eyes, I saw stars - streaking, bursting, falling everywhere in ecstatic fireworks - a whole galaxy.

From my little black journal, March 2005

...There had just been rain. It was sunset, and the wind was blowing unsteadily, the clouds were moving [faster] than usual, and the sunset cast a sandy salmon color on the clouds, trees, cars, houses, surface of the road. And because of the rainwater, everything was glistening and glowing, and the air smelled stale. It was a completely different dimension, though I'd seen those roads every day and driven on them as well. ...it was the dreamiest, most haunted, ghostly drive I've ever taken. And then...we were facing dark storm clouds in the east, but I could see the western horizon in the rear-view mirror, blazingly bright. That, too, was weird.

From my black journal, March 2004

"What shame on me!" cried Heart, convulsing in her bed; "I heard the news of death; I knew when Blood stood still, And when a trembling Hand to my dominion fled, Pursued from Spine to Forearm by a charging chill. What shame on me! While features without feeling know What now to fear, and even Eyes for what to weep, I Heart, of suffering sovereign, suffer not the blow That sends the heartless shaking, shakes away their sleep!" With all despair, Heart turned her thoughts ten times, then twelve, But in them found no grief except the grief of sin; Then, seeking justice, threw and thrashed her traitor self Against the ribbed walls of her sequestered den. And sighed all passersby who heard that heaving chest, "Kate heard the news of death - behold her heart's distress!"

I'm tired of living up to worldly standards. I've become obsessed with exalting myself. I am arrogant. I'm using God's name to glorify myself. I'm sorry. I want to stop, but I don't know how. Lord Jesus, take this sin away. It's ruining our relationship. Take it away. I'm embarrassed to admit it to anyone, even on paper, but I admit it to You. Take it, please. Take it off my hands. I can't carry both an obsession and a healthy relationship with You. I can't serve two masters. Take the distraction out of my mind, and make me pure. Let my words be used to lift You, not me. Let my words inspire, not to turn people to me, but to You.

-Becca

still I must pray from far away and touch your throne with love alone

From my little black journal; Monday, March 7, 2005, 6:50 PM

I am writing excitement.  I am writing hope, freedom from the future.  I am writing nearness to God.  I am writing the joy of having reached my destination at last.  I am writing music.  I am writing poetry.  I am writing here.  I am writing home.

From my little black journal; February 21, 2005
